ArticleTitle.sentence: T-cell functional regions of the human IL-3 proximal promoter.

AbstractText.sentence: The human interleukin-3 (IL-3) gene is expressed almost exclusively in activated T cells.

event.clue: The human interleukin-3 (IL-3) gene is expressed almost exclusively in activated T cells.
The human interleukin-3 (IL-3) gene is expressed almost exclusively in activated T cells.

AbstractText.sentence: Its expression is regulated at both the transcriptional and post-transcriptional level.

event.clue: Its expression is regulated at both the transcriptional and post-transcriptional level.

AbstractText.sentence: We have previously shown that treatment of Jurkat T cells with phytohemaglutinin (PHA) and the phorbol ester, PMA, activated transcription initiation from the IL-3 gene.

event.clue: We have previously shown that treatment of Jurkat T cells with phytohemaglutinin (PHA) and the phorbol ester, PMA, activated transcription initiation from the IL-3 gene.

AbstractText.sentence: To define the regions of the gene required for transcription activation, we generated a series of reporter constructs containing different regions of the IL-3 gene 5' and 3' flanking sequences.

event.clue: To define the regions of the gene required for transcription activation, we generated a series of reporter constructs containing different regions of the IL-3 gene 5' and 3' flanking sequences.
To define the regions of the gene required for transcription activation, we generated a series of reporter constructs containing different regions of the IL-3 gene 5' and 3' flanking sequences.

AbstractText.sentence: Both positive and negative regulatory elements were identified in the proximal 5' flanking region of the IL-3 gene.
The promoter region between -173 and -60 contained the strongest activating elements.
The transcription factor AP-1 could bind to this positive activator region of the promoter.

event.clue: The transcription factor AP-1 could bind to this positive activator region of the promoter.

AbstractText.sentence: We also examined the function of the IL-3 CK-1/CK-2 elements that are present in many cytokine genes and found that they acted as a repressor of basal level expression when cloned upstream of a heterologous promoter but were also inducible by PMA/PHA.
